text:
I like the idea of doing something soft like increasing wait times.
But idk if that incentives the wrong things.
E.g. if a package is very stable tagging releases only rarely, so they care less about waiting.

It might make sense though if breaking releases take longer to automerge.
Though we need to still worry about perverse incentives.
E.g. what if this encourages people to tag changes that a breaking as nonbreaking.
I think though it wouldn't.

text: Besides, the feature / patch version distinction only really works if you are doing backports / LTSes. Otherwise, if you decide to only upgrade to new patch releases you will be stuck on a bad version as soon as the package makes a new feature since the old release you are on won't get any new bug fixes. And no package does backports. So if you limit yourself to patch releases you will almost immediately be on a worse buggier version.

FWIW, I like the idea of an “unstable”, or “staging” registry.
